answers.answer: hi! well, i would just like to point out my opinion that fatty liver is usually caused by lipids accumulating in the cells of the liver or hepatocytes, so i think it is possible. Mostly is fatty liver is associated with obesity, diabetes, hypertension, syndrome x. However, it is not the only cause, fatty liver has different contributing factors such as alcohlic intake. Just to make it short i could be an alcoholic fatty liver or a non alcoholic cause.  If your lipids are really that high then i suggest you take action with regards to that.  and regarding the platelets, yes, fatty liver especially if it is already chronic can affect platelets since the liver does produce thrombopoietin (stimulates production of platelets) which is a major hormone synthesized in the liver. Thus if the liver becomes affected, its function can be altered as well. On the other hand, your platelet becoming low could have other causes as well. Especially if this is the first time this has happened.

question: Hi everyone, quick question.  When i went in for a lipid panel my triglycerides were through the roof, at 981.  I think I have a major genetic component, because i am 26 years old, 5'8" and 150 lbs.  My question is prolonged triglycerides that high can cause fatty liver correct?  My main question is could this cause my platelet count to be a tad low?  On the same blood draw my CBC showed platelets at 135,000.  I realize this isnt crazy low, but low nonetheless.  Anyone care to shed some light on this?  Thanks so much.
title: Hyperlipidemia cause fatty liver?
